body.p:
I had intended to write to you yesterday and today, but
have been so much hurried as to determine me to defer
it till I could write at some length; but a passage in your
letter just received stating that Mr E. P. Cohen intended being
here on Thursday compels me to write you at once, although it is
near ten, and I have just returned home. The book was as I
told you, it would be, sent off by Mr. Barrington in a parcel
directed to Mr. Herman, who received the first books. It
is wrapped up in white printing paper, directed to Mr E. P.
Cohen Baltimore; do try to get it at once, and hand it over
to Mr Cohen, or else give him another copy, and no
doubt an opportunity will offer to send off the fine copy at
some future day. I trust however that it is safe and sound
in your place. If I can I will see Mr Cohen at the warf,
but there is some doubt whether I can be in time. This
letter will be in Bal. tomorrow afternoon, in time to look for
the book, and I really regret that it should have had so
unfortunate a time reaching its destination. Recollect Human
sent by Haswell, Barrington & Haswell. No doubt it
can readily be found.__Of the images book 112 leaves an
up, and by Thursday I expect to have 130, or thereabouts.__A gene
ral feeling of sympathy is expressed for Mr Cohen; for the loss
of his wife; the family seem indeed to have had their troubles lately.
What can one say to console them? let us hope that the Lord of Consola
tion will send his spirit to comfort them and to uphold them in their
afflictions. Amen

Samuel Etting is in town, and intends leaving on Wednesday morning with his family
I thought of sending a letter by him but fearing it would be too late. I sentet these
few lines, in order to have sent off by the morning's mail.

I have been in the fashion, and had a cold, but it appears to be wearing away.
When are you coming on? Let it be soon, as many are anxious to see you,
? of failures in town, some for heavy amounts, one Comely for 3 ½ mill:
As young YehuR, Sol. Andrews, it appears has made a great swindle
for ¼ Million in Mobile. His house, consisting of himself & Hyman Andrews, who mar
ried Clarissa King, lately snapped in New York, and he perhaps thought to
indemnify himself; he has been caught, & I believe, locked up in New
Orleans. So much for high justice.__Good news are rather scarce
here and in New York; money very dear, even for the best notes two
to three per cent northern asked; curious indeed. I hope that the
Cohens will stand it though I fear they will have a hard trip as
so many private bankers all over the country have failed. Particularly
I fear, that St. John in New York owes them much, too much
for safety. I see but few people, but yet I believe that I guess right.
Joseph Moss I told you promised to pay me $200 per annum, payable
1 May & November, but as he has failed, I shall not present my bill
now, at least I shall wait, whether he will send me word or not.
Even in my little way I stand a chance of losing a little, but as I have
not built much hope upon his word, I do not think any thing of
it. He used to say so much against David, and now he has come to the

same himself. He has perhaps forgotten, but I have not.
Now has the above forgotten! Retribution!__You need not mention
the contents of this to any one, but amt; as I do not wish my
opinions to be made more public than necessary.__

I have not spoken since my book was published, and
I have not yet resolved how to do. What is your opinion?
Wishing you a perfect restoration to health

N.B. I have payt. to make till
July 4; and I hope to collect enough
before then to meet my engagements; if not I will
know, as you told me 100.

My love to aunty & Mrs Dr P. Mrssrs Judah & Block, ?
Block and the girls. Give my best regards to Mr Etting
and his daughters, also to the Messrs Cohen, with the expression
of my sympathy for their bereavement.
Paper torn near center right, obscuring some words or parts of words.
